step.name: Learn more about advanced data handling.
step.text: Data preprocessing is probably where you spend most of your time as an analyst. There are two general groups of data handling: blending and cleansing. This and the next tutorial will discuss some of the most important operations for data cleansing.
step.info: Blending is about transforming a data set from one state to another or combining multiple data sets. Cleansing is about improving the data so that modeling will deliver better results.
step.text: Let's look at the Titanic data again. You might remember from before that it contains some missing values depicted by question marks in the data. You can also see the number of missing values for each attribute in the Statistics view. Missing values are a problem for many data preprocessing or modeling operations. This tutorial will show you the most common approaches for removing or replacing missing values.
step.info: This is the second set of RapidMiner tutorials. Make sure you you've completed the first set before clicking next!

step.name: Prepare the data.

tasks.task: Drag the Titanic data into the process.
Hover your mouse pointer over the output port and wait for the tooltip to show the meta data.
Press F3 while the tooltip is shown. It is now transformed into a window and you can scroll down to see the information about all the columns.
Check for columns with missing values.

step.info: There are five attributes with missing values: Age, Passenger Fare, Cabin, Port of Embarkation, and Life Boat. Cabin and Life Boat have the most missing values, so let's deal with them first.

step.name: Remove attributes with too many missings.

tasks.task: Add a new operator Select Attributes.
Connect the new operator to the Retrieve operator and the output to the result port "res" on the right.
In Parameters, change the attribute filter type to Subset and select all attributes but Cabin and Life Boat. This means that those two will be removed by the operator.
Click on the Statistics tab and check which attributes with missing values are still left.

step.info: We removed Cabin because almost all values in this column were missing and the remaining values probably didn't contain a lot of useful information. We removed Life Boat for similar reasons and because this attribute is strongly correlated to the label. The attribute Age also has a significant number of missing values, but we will handle this using a different method next.

step.name: Replace missing values.

tasks.task: Search for the operator Replace Missing Values and add it to the process. You can drop it on the connection line between Select Attributes and the result port (move the mouse pointer until the connection is highlighted before you drop the new operator). This way you do not need to manually reconnect the operators.
In the Parameters of this operator, use single for the attribute filter type and select Age for attribute.

step.info: Dropping operators on connection lines often saves you the manual work of creating the connections yourself. Don't worry if you did not hit the connection line with your first try - just re-connect the operators manually in this case.

You will see in the Statistics tab that only a few examples with missing values are left. When we ran this process, the missing values for Age were replaced with the average value of Age - this is a common technique for handling a lot of missing values for an attribute. Because there are only a few missing values left, we can safely filter these examples out of the data set.

step.name: Remove examples with missing values.
step.info: You have used the Filter Examples operator already before, but this time we will use some advanced settings to remove examples that have missing values for their attributes.

tasks.task: Search for Filter Examples and drop it again on the connection line to the result port. In case you miss the connection, you can of course always manually connect the operator instead.
Note the link at the bottom of the Parameters panel which shows/hides advanced parameters Click on Show advanced parameters to display all operator parameters.
New parameters should appear. Set the condition class to no_missing_attributes.

step.name: Congratulations!
step.text: Great, you successfully handled missing values using three different approaches: Removing columns with missing values, replacing missing values with other values, and removing examples with missing values. Try solving the challenges below before you start the next tutorial:

questions.question: Check the Statistics tab - does it still show missing values for any of the columns?
Why is it not a good idea to just filter out the examples right away instead of removing attributes and replacing the missings in Age?
Right-click on Select Attributes and disable the operator. Do the same with Replace Missing Values. What do you expect if you re-run the process now? Try it!
How many examples are left in the data set now?
